case_name: Delhi Cloth and General Mills Co. Ltd. v. Union of India

facts.text: This is Civil Appeal No. 1424 of 1966.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 1424 of 1966.

facts.text: Appeal from the order dated February 11, 1965 of the Punjab High Court, Circuit Bench at Delhi in Civil Writ No. 3-D of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the order dated February 11, 1965 of the Punjab High Court, Circuit Bench at Delhi in Civil Writ No. 3-D of 1963.

facts.text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Grover, J.

anchor.surface_text: R. Gokhale, D.R. Thadani and A.N. Goyal, for the. appellant. Jagdish Swarup, Solicitor-General, L.M. Singhvi and R.N. Sachthey, for the respondents. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Grover, J.

facts.text: Delhi Cloth and General Mills Co. Ltd. operates a number of industrial establishments which are factories within the meaning of s. 2(m) of the Factories Act 1948 in the Delhi area.

anchor.surface_text: The Delhi Cloth and General Mills Co. Ltd. operates within the Delhi area a number of industrial establishments which are factories within the meaning of s. 2 m  of the Act.

facts.text: The company has to pay a total sum of Rs. 12,775.00 as annual licence fee for all its factories in Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: The companypany has to pay a total sum of Rs. 12,775.00 as annual licence. fee for all its factories in Delhi, the fees being calculated according to the Horse Power

facts.text: Fees calculated according to the Horse Power and the maximum number of workers to be employed on any day during the year as given in the Schedule.

anchor.surface_text: the fees being calculated according to the Horse Power and the maximum in number of workers to be employed on any day during the year as given in the Schedule.

facts.text: The maximum fee that is payable is Rs. 2,000/- for a factory.

anchor.surface_text: The maximum fee that is payable is Rs. 2,000/- for a factory.

facts.text: Factories can be run only after registration and under a licence granted under the Act and the Rules on payment of the prescribed fee.

anchor.surface_text: The factories can be run only after registration and under a licence granted under the Act and the Rules on payment of the prescribed fee.

facts.text: Licence renewed every year under R. 7 on payment of the same fee as paid at the time of granting.

anchor.surface_text: The licence is renewed every year under R. 7 on payment of the same fee which is paid at the time of the granting of the licence.

facts.text: Every licence granted or renewed remains in force up to December 31 of the year for which it is granted or renewed.

anchor.surface_text: Every licence granted or renewed remains in force up to December 31, of the year for which it is granted or renewed.

facts.text: In January 1963 the company filed a petition under Arts. 226 and 227 of the Constitution in the High Court challenging the validity of the Rules.

anchor.surface_text: In January 1963 the companypany filed a petition under Arts. 226 and 227 o,f the Constitution in the High Court challenging the validity of the Rules under which the licence fee

facts.text: The petition challenged Rule 7 read with Rule 5 and its Schedule of the Delhi Factories Rules 1950 made under s. 112 of the Factories Act 1948.

anchor.surface_text: for renewal of the licence for each of its factories in Delhi was being levied and companylected i.e.R. 7 read with R. 5 and its, Schedule of the Delhi Factories Rules 1950

facts.text: This petition was dismissed by a division bench on February 11, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: This petition was dismissed by a division bench on February 11, 1965.

facts.text: The company then filed the present appeal by certificate.

anchor.surface_text: The companypany then filed the present appeal by certificate.

facts.text: Falshaw C.J. delivered the judgment of the division bench.

anchor.surface_text: Falshaw C.J., who delivered the judgment of the division bench was of the view

facts.text: High Court observed that at least 60% of the amount realised as licence fee was being utilised on running the department.

anchor.surface_text: It was further observed on an examination of the affidavit which had been placed before the companyrt that at least 60. of the amount realised as licence fee was being utilised on running the department.

facts.text: The High Court finding that 60% of licence fees was spent on services is a finding of fact and final.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court further found, which finding being of fact, must be companysidered as final that 60 of the amount of licence fees which were being realized was actually spent

facts.text: In the return filed in High Court, stated that fees charged for running the Factory Inspectorate which provides free inspection and expert advice.

anchor.surface_text: In the return which was filed in the High Court to the writ petition it was stated in paragraph 8 that the fees were being charged for the running of the whole establishment including the Factory Inspectorate

facts.text: Appellant company never made out case before High Court that collections merged in general public revenue.

anchor.surface_text: Before the High Court the appellant companypany never made out any case that the companylections on .account of the licence fee were merged in the general public revenue

facts.text: The amount paid as licence fee is a fee and not a tax.

anchor.surface_text: There can be numbermanner of doubt that the amount which the appellant companypany has to pay as licence fee is number in the nature of a tax but is a fee which companyld be properly levied.

facts.text: In Liberty Cinema case, licence fee raised from Rs. 400/- to Rs. 6,000/- per year.

anchor.surface_text: In that case the licence fee had been raised from Rs. 400/- to Rs. 6,000/- per year.

issues.text: the question of the validity of Rule 7 read with Rule 5 and its Schedule of the Delhi Factories Rules 1950 made under s. 112 of the Factories Act 1948

anchor.surface_text: Circuit Bench, Delhi involving the question of the validity of Rule 7 read with Rule 5 and its Schedule of the Delhi Factories Rules 1950 made under s. 112 of the Factories Act 1948, hereinafter called the Act. The impugned Rules relate to the grant of a licence

issues.text: whether the payment made for renewal of the licence entails services which can reasonably be regarded to be commensurate with the amount so charged and whether the element of quid pro quo which distinguishes a fee from a tax is absent

anchor.surface_text: The principal point which has been canvassed on behalf of the appellant company is that the payment made for renewal of the licence was and is only to endorse the licence as valid ,for the next year and the amount charged for the renewal thereof cannot and does number entail services which can reasonably be regarded to be commensurate with the amount so charged. In other words the element of quid-pro- quo which distinguishes a fee from a tax is absent and lacking.

issues.text: whether a fee for a licence or a renewal thereof in circumstances similar to the present case is in substance and effect a tax

anchor.surface_text: that the High Court failed to apply the principles which are settled by certain decisions of this Court for determining whether a fee for a licence or a renewal thereof in circumstances similar to the present case is in substance and effect a tax. He has relied largely on Corporation of Calcutta Another v. Liberty Cinema 1 . In that case the licence fee had been raised from Rs. 400/- to Rs. 6,000/- per year.

issues.text: whether the levy is in the nature of a fee

anchor.surface_text: It is difficult to agree. In each case where the question arises whether the levy is in the nature of a fee the entire scheme of the statutory provisions, the duties and obligations imposed on the inspecting staff and the nature of work done by them will have to be examined for the purpose of determining the rendering of the services which would make the levy a ,fee.

issues.text: whether there is a reasonable relation between the levy and the expenses incurred for rendering the service

anchor.surface_text: A levy in the nature of a fee does number cease to be of that character merely because there is an element of companypulsion or companyrciveness present in it, number is it a postulate of a fee that it must have direct relation to the actual services rendered by the authority to individual who obtains the benefit of service. If with a view to provide a specific service, levy is imposed by law and expenses for maintaining the service are met out of the amounts companylected there being a reasonable relation between the levy and the expenses incurred for render-

arguments.claim: Payment for renewal of licence only endorses it as valid for next year and does not entail services commensurate with amount charged; lacks quid pro quo distinguishing fee from tax

anchor.surface_text: The principal point which has been canvassed on behalf of the appellant companypany is that the payment made for renewal of the licence was and is only to endorse the licence as valid ,for the next year and the amount charged for the renewal thereof cannot and does number entail services which can reasonably be regarded to be companymensurate with the amount so charged. In other words the element of quid-pro- quo which distinguishes a fee from a tax is absent and lacking.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: f. Section 9 gives the powers of the Inspectors. They can enter any factory and inter alia make examination of the premises, plant and machinery. Unde

arguments.court_reasoning: Entire scheme of Act shows inspectors render services like advice, examinations, orders preventing dangers; 60% of fees spent on department; reasonable relation exists

arguments.claim: Act contains provisions for owners to render benefits/services to workmen; Inspectors ensure compliance and constitute policing agency, not services to factory owners or workmen

anchor.surface_text: The Act, it is pointed out companytains specific provisions for rendering of benefit and service to the workmen by the owners of the factories. The Inspectors who are .appointed under the Act to ensure that its provisions are companyplied with by the factory owners companystitute a policing agency and it is number possible to say that the power and duties of the Inspectors when exercised and carried out amount to services rendered for the benefit of the factory owners or the workmen.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: f. Section 9 gives the powers of the Inspectors. They can enter any factory and inter alia make examination of the premises, plant and machinery. Unde

arguments.court_reasoning: Inspectors provide technical advice, guidance, preventive orders under various sections benefiting owners by averting dangers and ensuring compliance

arguments.claim: Work by Inspectors ensuring implementation of Act's beneficent provisions for workers' health and welfare is service rendered in return for renewal fee

anchor.surface_text: Falshaw C.J., who delivered the judgment of the division bench was of the view that the work carried out by the Inspectors under the Act of seeing that all its beneficient provisions for the health and welfare of the workers employed in the factories were fully implemented must definitely be regarded as services rendered in return for the fee levied for the annual renewal of the licence for the factory.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: f. Section 9 gives the powers of the Inspectors. They can enter any factory and inter alia make examination of the premises, plant and machinery. Unde

arguments.court_reasoning: Agreed based on detailed examination of Act's provisions on inspecting staff duties and services

anchor.surface_text: Mr. H.R. Gokhale for the appellant companypany has companytended that the High Court failed to apply the principles which are settled by certain decisions of this Court for determining whether a fee for a licence or a renewal thereof in circumstances similar to the present case is in substance and effect a tax. He has relied largely on Corporation of Calcutta Another v. Liberty Cinema 1 . In that case the licence fee had been raised from Rs. 400/- to Rs. 6,000/- per year.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: f. Section 9 gives the powers of the Inspectors. They can enter any factory and inter alia make examination of the premises, plant and machinery. Unde

arguments.court_reasoning: Liberty Cinema distinguishable as no service rendered there; here services under Act's scheme

arguments.claim: Fees charged for running Factory Inspectorate which provides free inspection and expert technical advice to factory owners on safety, health, welfare, compliance

anchor.surface_text: In the return which was filed in the High Court to the writ petition it was stated in paragraph 8 that the fees were being charged for the running of the whole establishment including the Factory Inspectorate which in its turn provides free inspection and expert technical advice etc., to factory owners in matters companynected with safety, health welfare and the allied matters in respect of companypliance with the provisions of the Factories Act.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: f. Section 9 gives the powers of the Inspectors. They can enter any factory and inter alia make examination of the premises, plant and machinery. Unde

arguments.court_reasoning: Supported by Act's provisions detailing inspectors' advisory and preventive roles

arguments.claim: Inspectors only ensure statutory compliance and launch prosecutions; functions confined to that

anchor.surface_text: According to Mr. Gokhale the Inspectors only carry out the duties laid on them under the Act and all that they have to do is to ensure that the statutory provisions and the rules are carried out properly and launch prosecutions against factory owners under the provisions of Chapter X of the Act in case of any breach or default on the part of the factory owners.

arguments.court_reasoning: Inspectors give advice, guidance, issue preventive orders under safety provisions, benefiting owners

arguments.claim: Levy is fee as entire Act scheme, inspecting staff duties, provide services making it a fee; distinguishes Liberty Cinema; follows precedents like Sudhundra Thirtha, Ratilal where supervision/control is service

anchor.surface_text: It is difficult to agree. In each case where the question arises whether the levy is in the nature of a fee the entire scheme of the statutory provisions, the duties and obligations imposed on the inspecting staff and the nature of work done by them will have to be examined for the purpose of determining the rendering of the services which would make the levy a ,fee. It is quite apparent that in the Liberty Cinema case it was found that numberservice of any kind was being or companyld be rendered and for that reason the levy was held to be a tax and number a fee.

anchor.surface_text: A levy in the nature of a fee does number cease to be of that character merely because there is an element of companypulsion or companyrciveness present in it, number is it a postulate of a fee that it must have direct relation to the actual services rendered by the authority to individual who obtains the benefit of service. If with a view to provide a specific service, levy is imposed by law and expenses for maintaining the service are met out of the amounts companylected there being a reasonable relation between the levy and the expenses incurred for render-

holdings.text: There can be no manner of doubt that the amount which the appellant company has to pay as licence fee is not in the nature of a tax but is a fee which could be properly levied.

anchor.surface_text: There can be numbermanner of doubt that the amount which the appellant companypany has to pay as licence fee is number in the nature of a tax but is a fee which companyld be properly levied.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Services rendered by inspecting staff under Factories Act provide quid pro quo; High Court finding of 60% expenditure on department final; no evidence of merger in general revenue; follows precedents on supervision fees; distinguishes Liberty Cinema.

holdings.text: The High Court further found, which finding being of fact, must be considered as final that 60% of the amount of licence fees which were being realized was actually spent on services rendered to the factory owners.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court further found, which finding being of fact, must be companysidered as final that 60 of the amount of licence fees which were being realized was actually spent

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court factual finding on expenditure binding on appeal.

holdings.text: In our judgment the present case falls within the other class of cases to which reference has been made in which contributions for the purpose of maintaining an authority and the staff for supervising and controlling public institutions like Maths etc. were held to be fee and not tax.

anchor.surface_text: It is quite apparent that in the Liberty Cinema case it was found that numberservice of any kind was being or companyld be rendered and for that reason the levy was held to be a tax and number a fee.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Entire scheme of Factories Act, duties of inspecting staff provide services unlike Liberty Cinema where no services rendered.

holdings.text: We do not consider that the functions and duties of the Inspectorate are confined only to the limited task which has been suggested on behalf of the appellant company.

anchor.surface_text: According to Mr. Gokhale the Inspectors only carry out the duties laid on them under the Act and all that they have to do is to ensure that the statutory provisions and the rules are carried out properly and launch prosecutions against factory owners under the provisions of Chapter X of the Act in case of any breach or default on the part of the factory owners. We do number companysider that the functions and duties of the Inspectorate are companyfined only to the limited task which has been suggested on behalf of the appellant companypany.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Inspectors provide technical advice, guidance, preventive orders under safety, health provisions benefiting factory owners by averting dangers.

holdings.text: It can, therefore, hardly be contended that the levy of the licence fee was wholly unrelated to the expenditure incurred out of the total realisation.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court further found, which finding being of fact, must be companysidered as final that 60 of the amount of licence fees which were being realized was actually spent on services rendered to the factory owners. It can, therefore, hardly be companytended that the levy of the licence fee was wholly unrelated to the expenditure incurred out of the total realisation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: 60% of fees spent on services per final High Court finding establishes reasonable relation.

holdings.text: Before the High Court the appellant company never made out any case that the collections on account of the licence fee were merged in the general public revenue and were not appropriated in the manner laid down for the appropriation of expenses for the department concerned.

anchor.surface_text: Before the High Court the appellant companypany never made out any case that the companylections on .account of the licence fee were merged in the general public revenue

holdings.reasoning_summary: No case or evidence presented by appellant on merger into general revenue.

holdings.text: A levy in the nature of a fee does not cease to be of that character merely because there is an element of compulsion or coerciveness present in it, nor is it a postulate of a fee that it must have direct relation to the actual services rendered by the authority to individual who obtains the benefit of service. If with a view to provide a specific service, levy is imposed by law and expenses for maintaining the service are met out of the amounts collected there being a reasonable relation between the levy and the expenses incurred for rendering the service, the levy would be in the nature of a fee and not in the nature of a tax.

anchor.surface_text: The following observations in H.H. Sudhundra Thirtha Swamiar case 1  may be referred to with advantage A levy in the nature of a fee does number cease to be of that character merely because there is an element of companypulsion or companyrciveness present in it, number is it a postulate of a fee that it must have direct relation to the actual services rendered by the authority to individual who obtains the benefit of service.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Approves and applies test from Sudhundra Thirtha: compulsion ok, no need for individual direct service if reasonable relation to collective service costs.

precedents.citation: Corporation of Calcutta Another v. Liberty Cinema 1

anchor.surface_text: Corporation of Calcutta Another v. Liberty Cinema 1 . In that case the licence fee had been raised from Rs. 400/- to Rs. 6,000/- per year.

precedents.case_name: Corporation of Calcutta v. Liberty Cinema
precedents.cited_proposition: licence fee without reference to rendering any service or obligation to make bye-laws for services is a tax; inspection to ensure compliance is not a service to the licensee
precedents.cited_holding: the provision under which the licence had to be taken out for a cinema did not refer to the rendering of any service by the Corporation of Calcutta; inspection by the authorities could not be regarded as a service to the licensee

precedents.citation: H.H. Sudhundra Thirtha Swamiar v. Commissioner for Hindu Religious Charitable Endowments, Mysore 1

precedents.case_name: H.H. Sudhundra Thirtha Swamiyar v. Commissioner for Hindu Religious Charitable Endowments, Mysore
precedents.cited_proposition: service resulting in the control of the Math adipathi conferred special benefit on the institution which alone paid the levy; a fee does not cease to be a fee merely because of compulsion or lack of direct relation to services if there is reasonable relation to expenses

precedents.citation: Mahant Sri Jagannath Ramanui Das Anr. v. The State of Orissa Another 2

precedents.case_name: Mahant Sri Jagannath Ramanuj Das v. State of Orissa
precedents.cited_proposition: contributions levied for expenses of Commissioner and staff for effective control over trustees of Maths and temples is a fee not tax, as not merged in general revenue and for specific purpose
precedents.cited_holding: Two reasons: 1. payment demanded only for expenses of Commissioner and staff for administration of religious institution; 2. collections not merged in general public revenue

precedents.citation: Ratilal Panachand Gandhi v. The State of Bombay Others 3

anchor.surface_text: Ratilal Panachand Gandhi v. The State of Bombay Others 3  the contribution imposed under the Bombay Public Trusts Act was held to be fee and not tax.

precedents.case_name: Ratilal Panachand Gandhi v. State of Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: contribution under Bombay Public Trusts Act is fee not tax, as credited to special fund not merged in general revenue; services beneficial in public interest sufficient

edges.explanation: i1 explicitly questions the validity of Rule 7 read with Rule 5 of Delhi Factories Rules, which is the concept c6
Validity of Rule 5 as fee vs tax (i1) requires assessing quid pro quo element in licence payments (i2)
i2 questions whether licence fee payments under Rule 5 are commensurate with services, addressing the fee prescription in c5
i2 raises whether renewal payment under the rule entails commensurate services and quid pro quo, directly addressing the challenge to c6
i2 questions if services for licence renewal are commensurate with amount charged and involve quid pro quo, directly matching c7's criteria for fee (quid pro quo, services commensurate with fee)
i3 asks if licence renewal fee is in substance a tax, directly invoking c7's distinction between tax and fee
i4 questions if levy is in nature of a fee, core to c7's tax vs fee distinction
i5 asks if reasonable relation between levy and expenses for service, explicitly part of c7's definition of fee (reasonable relation to expenses)
